commit_message:
Fix CLI configs get test for plugins with more versions

When more versions are available for a certain plugin, only one of them
should be passed to the test.
The test could also try all the versions and all the plugins, but this
is a discussion of another review.

Change-Id: I32351c7bb240058727b21ab8ea3536cc2bf45a2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-tests refs/changes/48/383048/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Get plugin data: dynamically discover the output file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-08 17:13:13.000000000', 'files': ['sahara_tempest_plugin/tests/cli/plugins.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara-tests/commit/a3dfd276f264b0bf2c7ed868adaab297eeedb6f6', 'message': "Get plugin data: dynamically discover the output file

The format of the plugin file changed post-Newton (it includes also the
version number now), so instead of trying the various possible combination,
read the name returned by the command.
Fallback name: the new behavior (in case the output will be removed, which
can't happen for the already released versions).

Also, cleanup the file with the plugin data after the test.
Change-Id: I3d4a4005eda74b2c1c35b1f23b9ce27a1797c9c4
"}]
commit_message:
Get plugin data: dynamically discover the output file

The format of the plugin file changed post-Newton (it includes also the
version number now), so instead of trying the various possible combination,
read the name returned by the command.
Fallback name: the new behavior (in case the output will be removed, which
can't happen for the already released versions).

Also, cleanup the file with the plugin data after the test.
Change-Id: I3d4a4005eda74b2c1c35b1f23b9ce27a1797c9c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-tests refs/changes/88/395088/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os import remove import re outmsg = self.openstack('dataprocessing plugin configs get', params=''.join([plugin_name, ' ', version[0]])) outfile_match = re.search('configs was saved in "(.+)"', outmsg) if outfile_match: configs_file = outfile_match.group(1) else: configs_file = '%s_%s' % (plugin_name, version[0]) result = path.exists(configs_file) remove(configs_file)
deleted_lines: self.openstack('dataprocessing plugin configs get', params=''.join([plugin_name, ' ', version[0]])) result = path.exists(plugin_name)

As the following part of API-WG guidline[1],

 If a request contains a reference to a nonexistent resource in the

commit_message:
Add negative tests about update-volume API

As the following part of API-WG guidline[1],

 If a request contains a reference to a nonexistent resource in the
 body (not URI), the code should be 400 Bad Request. Do not use 404
 NotFound because :rfc:`7231#section-6.5.4` (section 6.5.4) mentions
 the origin server did not find a current representation for the
 target resource for 404 and representation for the target resource
 means a URI

Nova should return a NotFound(404) on this first test case, but it
should return a BadRequest response(400) in this second case, because
the second volume id is specified in a request body.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/http.rst#failure-code-clarifications

Depends-On: Ib781b116f5af713d64b5880858cc4f81c3da3977
Related-Bug: #1629110
Change-Id: I409c4fd53e272f6b15fb2a34068e3d003317290e

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 NEC Corporation. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import exceptions as lib_exc from tempest import test class VolumesAdminTestJSON(base.BaseV2ComputeAdminTest): @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(VolumesAdminTestJSON, cls).setup_clients() cls.servers_admin_client = cls.os_adm.servers_client @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(VolumesAdminTestJSON, cls).resource_setup() cls.server = cls.create_test_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') cls.volume1 = cls.create_volume() cls.volume2 = cls.create_volume() cls.attach_volume(cls.server, cls.volume1) @test.idempotent_id('309b5ecd-0585-4a7e-a36f-d2b2bf55259d') def test_update_attached_volume_with_nonexistent_volume_in_uri(self): nonexistent_volume = data_utils.rand_uuid() self.assertRaises(lib_exc.NotFound, self.servers_admin_client.update_attached_volume, self.server['id'], nonexistent_volume, volumeId=self.volume2['id']) @test.idempotent_id('7dcac15a-b107-46d3-a5f6-cb863f4e454a') def test_update_attached_volume_with_nonexistent_volume_in_body(self): nonexistent_volume = data_utils.rand_uuid() self.assertRaises(lib_exc.NotFound, self.servers_admin_client.update_attached_volume, self.server['id'], self.volume1['id'], volumeId=nonexistent_volume)

commit_message:
Optimize time trigger: remove the interval variable '_next_run_time'

Optimize time trigger in several aspects. This patch is the second
phase, which will remove the interval variable '_next_run_time'.

Change-Id: Iecf5e83ea0ee1cb7724847eb2e4a6b8d15d9158d
Closes-Bug: #1611232

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

Karbor already uses PBR:- setuptools.setup(
       setup_requires=['pbr>=1.8'],
       pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: If44d3d6a1bf03a87105b3e38270d1fc5a72f224c
Closes-Bug: #1608980

commit_message:
Replace SimpleProducer with KafkaProducer

SimpleProducer is marked as deprecated at kafka-python library [1].
The deprecated method causes "FailedPayloadsError: FailedPayloadsError" error.
This patch replaces SimpleProducer with KafkaProducer.

[1] http://kafka-python.readthedocs.io/en/1.1.1/simple.html

Change-Id: I7c979e1064c9c42e82ae71e2631a3d2bd0462839
Closes-bug: #1628456

deleted_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import yaml from nailgun.consts import TAG_OWNER_TYPES from nailgun.test import base class TestTagApi(base.BaseIntegrationTest): TAG = """ tag: my_tag has_primary: false """ owner_url = "/api/{}/{}/tags/" owner_map = { 'release': 'releases', 'cluster': 'clusters', 'plugin': 'plugins' } def setUp(self): super(TestTagApi, self).setUp() self.release = self.env.create_release() self.cluster = self.env.create_cluster(release_id=self.release.id) self.plugin = self.env.create_plugin(cluster=self.cluster) self.node = self.env.create_node(api=False, cluster_id=self.cluster.id, pending_roles=['controller'], pending_addition=True) self.tag_data = yaml.load(self.TAG) def _get_all_tags(self, owner, owner_id): return self.app.get(self.owner_url.format(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id), headers=self.default_headers) def _test_get_tags(self, owner, owner_id): n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self._get_all_tags(owner, owner_id) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertTrue([t for t in resp.json if t['id'] == n_tag['id']]) def test_get_release_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.release, self.release.id) def test_get_cluster_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id) def test_get_plugins_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.plugin, self.plugin.id) def test_create_get_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data) resp = self.env.get_tag(n_tag.json['id'], n_tag) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertDictEqual(resp.json, n_tag.json) def test_update_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) n_tag.update({'tag': 'other_tag', 'has_primary': True}) resp = self.env.update_tag(n_tag['id'], n_tag) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertDictEqual(resp.json, n_tag) def test_failed_update_read_only_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data.update({'read_only': True}) n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) n_tag.update({'tag': 'other_tag', 'has_primary': True}) resp = self.env.update_tag(n_tag['id'], n_tag, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) def test_delete_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag.json['id']) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 204) def test_failed_delete_read_only_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data.update({'read_only': True}) n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag['id'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) def test_failed_delete_assigned_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag['id'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("is assigned to node", resp.body) def test_assign_unassign_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 204) self.assertNotIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) def test_failed_assign_tag_twice(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 405) self.assertIn("are already assigned to", resp.body) def test_failed_unassign_not_assigned_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 405) self.assertIn("are not assigned to", resp.body) def test_failed_assign_tag_to_non_cluster_node(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) node = self.env.create_node(api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 403) self.assertIn("is not in a cluster", resp.body) def test_failed_create_tag_for_non_existent_cluster(self): cluster_ids = [c.id for c in self.env.clusters] owner_id = next(x for x in xrange(1, 1000) if x not in cluster_ids) owner = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster resp = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=True, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 404) self.assertIn("not found", resp.body) def test_failed_create_tag_with_incorrect_data(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data['has_primary'] = 'abc' resp = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data, api=True, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("is not of type", resp.body) def test_failed_assign_unassign_tag_by_name(self): resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, ['my_tag'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("only numeric", resp.body) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, ['my_tag'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("only numeric", resp.body)

deleted_lines: cls.create_tags(plugin_obj) def create_tags(cls, instance): from nailgun.objects import Tag tags = instance.tags_metadata roles = instance.roles_metadata # add creation of so-called tags for roles if tags are not # present in role's metadata. it's necessary for compatibility # with plugins without tags feature for role, meta in six.iteritems(roles): role_tags = meta.get('tags') if not role_tags: tags[role] = { 'tag': role, 'has_primary': meta.get('has_primary', False), } # it's necessary for auto adding tag when we are # assigning the role meta['tags'] = [role] roles.mark_dirty() for name, meta in six.iteritems(tags): data = { 'owner_id': instance.id, 'owner_type': consts.TAG_OWNER_TYPES.plugin, 'tag': name, 'has_primary': meta.get('has_primary', False), 'read_only': True } Tag.create(data) db().flush() @classmethod

commit_message:
Revert "Fix minor issues in tag API"

This reverts commit 319cb284c56d816613b6b74a492f0c31cd2fc4fa.

Change-Id: I564c9c0adda3509a20e85fa9a0d2f0620447ec23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/01/394801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import yaml from nailgun.consts import TAG_OWNER_TYPES from nailgun.test import base class TestTagApi(base.BaseIntegrationTest): TAG = """ tag: my_tag has_primary: false """ owner_url = "/api/{}/{}/tags/" owner_map = { 'release': 'releases', 'cluster': 'clusters', 'plugin': 'plugins' } def setUp(self): super(TestTagApi, self).setUp() self.release = self.env.create_release() self.cluster = self.env.create_cluster(release_id=self.release.id) self.plugin = self.env.create_plugin(cluster=self.cluster) self.node = self.env.create_node(api=False, cluster_id=self.cluster.id, pending_roles=['controller'], pending_addition=True) self.tag_data = yaml.load(self.TAG) def _get_all_tags(self, owner, owner_id): return self.app.get(self.owner_url.format(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id), headers=self.default_headers) def _test_get_tags(self, owner, owner_id): n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self._get_all_tags(owner, owner_id) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertTrue([t for t in resp.json if t['id'] == n_tag['id']]) def test_get_release_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.release, self.release.id) def test_get_cluster_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id) def test_get_plugins_tags(self): self._test_get_tags(TAG_OWNER_TYPES.plugin, self.plugin.id) def test_create_get_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data) resp = self.env.get_tag(n_tag.json['id'], n_tag) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertDictEqual(resp.json, n_tag.json) def test_update_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) n_tag.update({'tag': 'other_tag', 'has_primary': True}) resp = self.env.update_tag(n_tag['id'], n_tag) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertDictEqual(resp.json, n_tag) def test_failed_update_read_only_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data.update({'read_only': True}) n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) n_tag.update({'tag': 'other_tag', 'has_primary': True}) resp = self.env.update_tag(n_tag['id'], n_tag, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) def test_delete_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag.json['id']) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 204) def test_failed_delete_read_only_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data.update({'read_only': True}) n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag['id'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) def test_failed_delete_assigned_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) resp = self.env.delete_tag(n_tag['id'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("is assigned to node", resp.body) def test_assign_unassign_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 204) self.assertNotIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) def test_failed_assign_tag_twice(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']]) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn(n_tag['tag'], [t.tag.tag for t in self.node.tags]) resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 405) self.assertIn("are already assigned to", resp.body) def test_failed_unassign_not_assigned_tag(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 405) self.assertIn("are not assigned to", resp.body) def test_failed_assign_tag_to_non_cluster_node(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id n_tag = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=False) node = self.env.create_node(api=False) resp = self.env.assign_tag(node.id, [n_tag['id']], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 403) self.assertIn("is not in a cluster", resp.body) def test_failed_create_tag_for_non_existent_cluster(self): cluster_ids = [c.id for c in self.env.clusters] owner_id = next(x for x in xrange(1, 1000) if x not in cluster_ids) owner = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster resp = self.env.create_tag(owner, owner_id, self.tag_data, api=True, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 404) self.assertIn("not found", resp.body) def test_failed_create_tag_with_incorrect_data(self): owner, owner_id = TAG_OWNER_TYPES.cluster, self.cluster.id self.tag_data['has_primary'] = 'abc' resp = self.env.create_tag(self.owner_map[owner], owner_id, self.tag_data, api=True, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("is not of type", resp.body) def test_failed_assign_unassign_tag_by_name(self): resp = self.env.assign_tag(self.node.id, ['my_tag'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("only numeric", resp.body) resp = self.env.unassign_tag(self.node.id, ['my_tag'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 400) self.assertIn("only numeric", resp.body)

commit_message:
Add i18n-specs repo

I18n wants to create and use a specification repository
for more detail and concrete descriptions with formalized
specs. This spec repo uses the same acl as i18n repo.

commit_message:
Create governance-website repository

Create an openstack/governance-website repository to hold the
base neutral documents for the root of the governance.o.o
website. Publish jobs will be set up once the content is ready.

For more details, see:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack-infra/infra-specs/specs/neutral-governance-website.html

Change-Id: I5e7ca0e05d5d1614f17abbdf47c0b6f3761f3b63

commit_message:
Add coverage2sql project

coverage2sql is a tool for storing data of test coverage into a SQL
database. This is similar to subunit2sql but the data source is coverage
not subunit stream.

Change-Id: I8b0aa6c70f79d8552cc3113d5714e53587b08866

Use py35 for the periodic neutron-lib job.

commit_message:
Replace oslo_utils.timeutils.isotime

Function 'oslo_utils.timeutils.isotime()' is deprecated in version '1.6' and
will be removed in a future version. We  use datetime.datetime.isoformat()
instead. For more informations:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.utils/api/timeutils.html#oslo_utils.timeutils.isotime

Change-Id: Id8d5e5b05560808afdcc0bcc1bf8c4ff21af7987
Closes-Bug: #1514331

commit_message:
Merge the separated link lines on compute client

On current docstring of service clients, every link to API
reference is separated to 2 lines. That is unreadable on the
code and the documentation which is created from the docstring
also will be unreadablebecause of the separated link lines.

This patch merges the separated lines into a single line for the
readability.

Change-Id: Id06bd145c6c46f9302686152f2fcbde4a5eb1551

commit_message:
Fix gate problem related to  _error_checker()

Since I84e3be748af10b158037866e1ee4c1375b2c3541, the internal method
_error_checker() is changed and the ceilometer gate is broken.
This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I83a4899227e117e8f05ad179e5656ef6784f4a0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/48/389848/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Rewrite create-node.sh in Python.

Replaced create-node.sh with create-node.py. This script is used for
making libvirt guest domains during Devstack deployment. The new
Python script utilizes the following helper modules:

* libvirt - for making hypervisor calls for pool and domain creation
* netifaces - for retrieving network bridge address info
* pyroute2 - for setting up bridge interfaces
* ryu - for setting up OVS bridge interfaces

Change-Id: I2ee2fc8ac32f8de50768f5d7725265b16fff11da
Closes-Bug: 1596726
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/32/346832/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Create baremetal poseur nodes for ironic testing purposes.""" import argparse import libvirt import netifaces import os.path import subprocess as sp from xml.dom import minidom def get_env(var_name, def_value): """Fetch OS env var by name defaulting to backup value if not defined.""" if var_name in os.environ: return os.environ[var_name] else: return def_value def err_exit(msg, code=1): """Output error message and exit program with specified code.""" print("Error: " + msg) exit(code) parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( description='Creates baremetal poseur nodes for ironic testing purposes.') parser.add_argument('-n', required=True, metavar='<name>', help='domain name') parser.add_argument('-c', required=True, metavar='<cpus>', type=int, help='number of CPUs') parser.add_argument('-m', required=True, metavar='<mem>', type=int, help='memory size in kilobytes') parser.add_argument('-d', required=True, metavar='<disk>', type=int, help='volume disk size in gigabytes') parser.add_argument('-a', required=True, metavar='<arch>', help='CPU architecture') parser.add_argument('-b', required=True, metavar='<bridge>', help='bridge') parser.add_argument('-e', required=True, metavar='<emu>', help='emulator') parser.add_argument('-p', required=True, metavar='<port>', type=int, help='vbmc port') parser.add_argument('-f', required=True, metavar='<format>', help='volume disk format') parser.add_argument('-l', required=False, metavar='<logdir>', help='logging diretory') args = parser.parse_args() # Store command-line arguments in vars dom_name = args.n cpus = str(args.c) mem = str(args.m * 1024) # Append extra gig to disk size to allow fuzz for partition table # flavor size and registered size need to be different to actual size. disk_size = str(args.d + 1) arch = args.a bridge = args.b emu = args.e port = str(args.p) disk_format = args.f log_dir = args.l # Create log directory if supplied if log_dir: if os.path.exists(log_dir) is False: # Note: ignoring possible exceptions to stop execution if bad input os.makedirs(log_dir) elif os.path.isdir(log_dir) is False: err_exit("logs directory (" + log_dir + ") exists as a regular file") # Use environment defined or defaults for storage pool name and NIC driver pool_name = get_env('LIBVIRT_STORAGE_pool', 'default') nic_driver = get_env('LIBVIRT_NIC_DRIVER', 'virtio') # Make sure target directory exists tar_dir = "/var/lib/libvirt/images" if os.path.exists(tar_dir) is False: if sp.call(["sudo", "mkdir", tar_dir]) != 0: err_exit("unable to create target directory: " + tar_dir) elif os.path.isdir(tar_dir) is False: err_exit("target directory (" + tar_dir + ") exists as a regular file") # Open a connection to the hypervisor conn = libvirt.open(None) if conn is None: err_exit("failed to open connection to the hypervisor") try: # Skip creating a storage pool if one already exists storage_pool = conn.storagePoolLookupByName(pool_name) except libvirt.libvirtError: # Storage pool not found, spin up a new one xmldesc = """ <pool type='dir'> <name>%s</name> <capacity unit='bytes'>84516978688</capacity> <allocation unit='bytes'>5916213248</allocation> <available unit='bytes'>78600765440</available> <target> <path>%s</path> <permissions> <mode>0711</mode> <owner>-1</owner> <group>-1</group> </permissions> </target> </pool>""" storage_pool = conn.storagePoolDefineXML(xmldesc % (pool_name, tar_dir), 0) if storage_pool is None: err_exit("Failed to create storage pool: " + pool_name) if storage_pool.setAutostart(1) < 0: err_exit("Failed to set auto start property on pool: " + pool_name) # Start the storage pool if it's not already running if storage_pool.info()[0] != libvirt.VIR_CONNECT_LIST_STORAGE_POOLS_ACTIVE: if storage_pool.create(0) < 0: err_exit("Failed to set auto start property on pool: " + pool_name) # Create bridge and add VM interface to it. # Additional interface will be added to this bridge and # it will be plugged to OVS. # This is needed in order to have interface in OVS even # when VM is in shutdown state with open(os.devnull, "w") as devnull: sp.call(["sudo", "brctl", "addbr", "br-" + dom_name], stderr=devnull) if 0 != sp.call(["sudo", "ip", "link", "set", "br-" + dom_name, "up"]): err_exit("unable to set link state to UP: br-" + dom_name) if 0 != sp.call(["sudo", "ovs-vsctl", "--may-exist", "add-br", bridge]): err_exit("unable to add openvswitch bridge:" + bridge) if 0 != sp.call(["sudo", "ovs-vsctl", "--may-exist", "add-port", bridge, "ovs-" + dom_name, "--", "set", "Interface", "ovs-" + dom_name, "type=internal"]): err_exit("unable to add openvswitch port") if 0 != sp.call(["sudo", "ip", "link", "set", "ovs-" + dom_name, "up"]): err_exit("unable to set link state to UP: ovs-" + dom_name) with open(os.devnull, "w") as devnull: sp.call(["sudo", "brctl", "addif", "br-" + dom_name, "ovs-" + dom_name], stderr=devnull) try: # Skip new domain creation if it already exists domain = conn.lookupByName(dom_name) except libvirt.libvirtError: try: # Remove existing storage volume vol_name = ".".join([dom_name, disk_format]) storage_volume = storage_pool.storageVolLookupByName(vol_name) if storage_volume.wipe(0) < 0: err_exit("unable to physically wipe the volume form disk") if storage_volume.delete(0) < 0: err_exit("unable to logically remove the volume from storage pool") except libvirt.libvirtError: pass # Setup new volume definition xml = """ <volume type='file'> <name>%s</name> <capacity unit='G'>%s</capacity> <target> <path>%s</path> <format type='%s'/> <permissions> <mode>0600</mode> <owner>0</owner> <group>0</group> </permissions> </target> </volume>""" vol_path = "/".join([tar_dir, vol_name]) stgvol_xml = xml % (vol_name, disk_size, vol_path, disk_format) if os.path.exists("/etc/debian_version") and disk_format == "qcow2": prealloc_flag = libvirt.VIR_STORAGE_VOL_CREATE_PREALLOC_METADATA else: prealloc_flag = 0 # Create volume storage_volume = storage_pool.createXML(stgvol_xml, prealloc_flag) if storage_volume is None: err_exit("failed to create volume: " + vol_name + " in pool: " + pool_name) # Set the 'C' attribute to disable copy-on-write updates sp.call(["sudo", "chattr", "+C", vol_path]) if log_dir: vm_log = "--console-log " + log_dir + "/" + dom_name + "_console.log" else: vm_log = "" # Construct input for and call the configure-vm.py script cmd_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)) configure_cmd_path = "/".join([cmd_dir, "configure-vm.py"]) configure_vm_cmd = " ".join([configure_cmd_path, "--bootdev", "network", "--name", dom_name, "--image", "\"" + vol_path + "\"", "--arch", arch, "--cpus", cpus, "--memory", mem, "--libvirt-nic-driver", nic_driver, "--emulator", emu, "--bridge", "br-" + dom_name, "--disk-format", disk_format, vm_log]) with open(os.devnull, "w") as devnull: sp.call(configure_vm_cmd, shell=True, stdout=devnull) # Lookup newly created domain try: domain = conn.lookupByName(dom_name) except libvirt.libvirtError: err_exit("domain creation failed, check the logs") # Create a Virtual BMC for the node if IPMI is used with open(os.devnull, "w") as devnull: if sp.call(["which", "vbmc"], stdout=devnull) == 0: sp.call(["vbmc", "add", dom_name, "--port", port], stderr=devnull) sp.call(["vbmc", "start", dom_name], stderr=devnull) # Echo interface MAC address xml = minidom.parseString(domain.XMLDesc()) macs = xml.getElementsByTagName("mac") if len(macs) == 0: err_exit("no mac address for domain, something went wrong") vm_mac = macs[0].getAttribute("address") try: ifaces = netifaces.ifaddresses(bridge) link = ifaces[netifaces.AF_LINK] if len(link) == 0: err_exit("link layer interface for '%s' does not exist" % bridge) except ValueError: err_exit("bridge '%s' does not exist" % bridge) except KeyError: err_exit("link layer interface for '%s' does not exist" % bridge) try: switch_id = link[0]['addr'] print(" ".join([vm_mac, port, bridge, switch_id, "ovs-" + dom_name])) except KeyError: err_exit("no interface address for '%s'" % bridge)

added_lines: import mockredis = zmq_matchmaker_redis.redis sentinel = zmq_matchmaker_redis.redis_sentinel def mock_redis(self): if redis is None: self.skipTest("redis not available") else: redis_patcher = mock.patch.object(redis, 'StrictRedis') self.addCleanup(redis_patcher.stop) return redis_patcher.start() def mock_sentinel(self): if sentinel is None: self.skipTest("sentinel not available") else: sentinel_patcher = mock.patch.object(sentinel, 'Sentinel') self.addCleanup(sentinel_patcher.stop) return sentinel_patcher.start() def test_empty_url(self): self.mock_redis() self.mock_redis() self.mock_sentinel() self.mock_redis() self.mock_redis() self.mock_sentinel()

commit_message:
Graduate to oslo.i18n and cleanup incubator usage

Graduate from Oslo Incubator to oslo.i18n library.
Cleanup of unused Oslo Incubator utils.
Added optional enable_lazy() usage.

Change-Id: I5ec02477f3f52f4d7097669120581e82cced3748
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fixing 'join' task completion logic

* The entire workflow was failing if one of a join task's inbound
  tasks failed even if there was 'on-error' clause in task
  defaults.

Change-Id: Ie5864740ed6356d87bcedf9a6cfd0e733e8795a8
Closes-Bug: #1635841
(cherry picked from commit 9ce3a75aa99b802db70995d233aa7f7d65047b64)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/02/392102/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_delete_join_completion_check_on_stop(self): def test_delete_join_completion_check_on_execution_delete(self): def test_no_workflow_error_after_inbound_error(self): wf_text = """--- version: "2.0" wf: output: continue_flag: <% $.get(continue_flag) %> task-defaults: on-error: - change_continue_flag tasks: task_a: action: std.fail on-success: - task_c: <% $.get(continue_flag) = null %> - task_a_process task_a_process: action: std.noop task_b: on-success: - task_c: <% $.get(continue_flag) = null %> task_c: join: all change_continue_flag: publish: continue_flag: false """ wf_service.create_workflows(wf_text) wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('wf', {}) self.await_workflow_success(wf_ex.id)

commit_message:
Update api_class in volume encryption section

In the config reference volume encryption section, the api_class
needs to reflect settings which support the Castellan key
manager with Barbican.

Change-Id: Id37e423006387b65ddb51b0320fda3c5d33b7421
Closes-Bug: #1639886

commit_message:
Transition docs to OSC

Neutronclient is going to be deprecated.
Use OpenStack client commands in docs.

Change-Id: Iacb59e668364ef748d340145d1fa73858ae710d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/48/395048/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ openstack network create public --external $ openstack subnet create --network public --subnet-range 172.16.1.0/24 $ openstack network list --external $ openstack network create net1 $ openstack subnet create --network net1 --subnet-range 10.0.0.0/24 $ openstack network create net2 $ openstack subnet create --network net2 --subnet-range 10.0.1.0/24 $ openstack router create router1 $ openstack router add subnet router1 SUBNET1_UUID $ openstack router add subnet router1 SUBNET2_UUID $ openstack router set --external-gateway EXT_NET_ID router1 $ openstack router list $ openstack router show ROUTER_ID $ openstack port list --router ROUTER_ID $ openstack port list --router ROUTER_NAME $ openstack port list -c ID -c "Fixed IP Addresses" --server INSTANCE_ID $ openstack floating ip create EXT_NET_ID $ openstack floating ip add port FLOATING_IP_ID --port-id INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID $ openstack floating ip create EXT_NET_ID --subnet SUBNET_ID $ openstack floating ip create --port INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID EXT_NET_ID $ openstack floating ip list $ openstack floating ip list --port INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID $ openstack floating ip remove port FLOATING_IP_ID $ openstack floating ip delete FLOATING_IP_ID $ openstack router remove subnet router1 SUBNET_ID $ openstack router delete router1 $ openstack security group create webservers \ $ openstack security group list $ openstack security group rule create --ingress \ --protocol tcp SECURITY_GROUP_UUID $ openstack security group rule list $ openstack security group rule delete SECURITY_GROUP_RULE_UUID $ openstack security group delete SECURITY_GROUP_UUID $ openstack port create port1 --security-group SECURITY_GROUP_ID1 \ --security-group SECURITY_GROUP_ID2 --network NETWORK_ID $ openstack port set --no-security-group PORT_ID $ openstack network meter label create LABEL1 \ --description "DESCRIPTION_LABEL1" $ openstack network meter label list $ openstack network meter label show LABEL_UUID $ openstack network meter label show LABEL1 $ openstack network meter label delete LABEL_UUID $ openstack network meter label delete LABEL1 $ openstack network meter label rule create LABEL_UUID \ --remote-ip-prefix CIDR \ --direction DIRECTION --exclude $ openstack network meter label rule create label1 \ --remote-ip-prefix 10.0.0.0/24 --direction ingress $ openstack network meter label rule create label1 \ --remote-ip-prefix 20.0.0.0/24 --exclude $ openstack network meter label rule list $ openstack network meter label rule show RULE_UUID $ openstack network meter label rule delete RULE_UUID
deleted_lines: $ neutron net-create public --router:external True $ neutron subnet-create public 172.16.1.0/24 $ neutron net-list --router:external True $ neutron net-create net1 $ neutron subnet-create net1 10.0.0.0/24 $ neutron net-create net2 $ neutron subnet-create net2 10.0.1.0/24 $ neutron router-create router1 $ neutron router-interface-add router1 SUBNET1_UUID $ neutron router-interface-add router1 SUBNET2_UUID $ neutron router-gateway-set router1 EXT_NET_ID $ neutron router-list $ neutron router-show ROUTER_ID $ neutron router-port-list ROUTER_ID $ neutron router-port-list ROUTER_NAME $ neutron port-list -c id -c fixed_ips --device_id INSTANCE_ID $ neutron floatingip-create EXT_NET_ID $ neutron floatingip-associate FLOATING_IP_ID INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID $ neutron floatingip-create EXT_NET_ID SUBNET_ID $ neutron floatingip-create --port_id INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID EXT_NET_ID $ neutron floatingip-list $ neutron floatingip-list --port_id INTERNAL_VM_PORT_ID $ neutron floatingip-disassociate FLOATING_IP_ID $ neutron floatingip-delete FLOATING_IP_ID $ neutron router-interface-delete router1 SUBNET_ID $ neutron router-delete router1 $ neutron security-group-create webservers \ $ neutron security-group-list $ neutron security-group-rule-create --direction ingress \ --protocol tcp --port_range_min 80 --port_range_max 80 \ SECURITY_GROUP_UUID $ neutron security-group-rule-list $ neutron security-group-rule-delete SECURITY_GROUP_RULE_UUID $ neutron security-group-delete SECURITY_GROUP_UUID $ neutron port-create --security-group SECURITY_GROUP_ID1 \ --security-group SECURITY_GROUP_ID2 NETWORK_ID $ neutron port-update --no-security-groups PORT_ID Disabling port security ----------------------- Security groups and anti-spoofing rules can be problematic for some applications. MAC anti-spoofing prevents applications from sending or receiving packets with source or destination addresses that do not match the configured address of a port. For example, multicast packets use a multicast group address as the destination address rather than the address of the virtual machine. While all security groups can be removed from a port, disabling MAC anti-spoofing requires the port security extension. .. note:: - By default port security is enabled on every port. - All security groups must be removed from a port before disabling port security. This table shows example neutron commands to selectively disable or enable port security for a single port: .. list-table:: **Port security operations** :widths: 30 50 :header-rows: 1 * - Operation - Command * - Disable port security on a port. - .. code-block:: console $ neutron port-update --port-security-enabled=False PORT_ID * - Enable port security on a port. - .. code-block:: console $ neutron port-update --port-security-enabled=True PORT_ID Port security can also be disabled when a port is created using ``port_security_enabled`` attribute. The ``port_security_enabled`` attribute can also be used at the network level to disable port security by default for all ports in a specific network. $ neutron meter-label-create LABEL1 --description "DESCRIPTION_LABEL1" $ neutron meter-label-list $ neutron meter-label-show LABEL_UUID $ neutron meter-label-show LABEL1 $ neutron meter-label-delete LABEL_UUID $ neutron meter-label-delete LABEL1 $ neutron meter-label-rule-create LABEL_UUID CIDR --direction DIRECTION \ --excluded $ neutron meter-label-rule-create label1 10.0.0.0/24 --direction ingress $ neutron meter-label-rule-create label1 20.0.0.0/24 --excluded $ neutron meter-label-rule-list $ neutron meter-label-rule-show RULE_UUID $ neutron meter-label-rule-delete RULE_UUID

commit_message:
Clean create_snapshots_in_db method

Currently we have code in create_snapshots_in_db that should be in
_create_snapshot_in_db_validate, and we have code in this last method
that is never used.

This patch cleans this up to make it more readable and remove unused
code.

Change-Id: Iae654cee995f3244b02f27d7c0b3de6a55d7f356
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/15/367615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._create_snapshot_in_db_validate(context, volume) def _create_snapshot_in_db_validate(self, context, volume): if volume['status'] == 'error': msg = _("The snapshot cannot be created when the volume is " "in error status.") LOG.error(msg)
deleted_lines: self._create_snapshot_in_db_validate(context, volume, True) if volume['status'] == 'error': msg = _("The snapshot cannot be created when the volume is " "in error status.") LOG.error(msg) raise exception.InvalidVolume(reason=msg) def _create_snapshot_in_db_validate(self, context, volume, force): if ((not force) and (volume['status'] != "available")): msg = _("Snapshot cannot be created because volume %(vol_id)s " "is not available, current volume status: " "%(vol_status)s.") % {'vol_id': volume['id'], 'vol_status': volume['status']}

subject: Handle region_name in openstack actions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-20 13:13:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/64124a5a3c44d7dfafe2c48bdef370d987474e68', 'message': 'Hanlde region in local and target cloud also.

User now could define the target region for the openstack actions.
It could be done via API together with multi-vim feature or statically
via mistral configuration file.

*Configuration changes*
New config group (os_actions) introduced for openstack action configuration.
Inside os_actions group two options are defined:
 - region_name
 - endpoint_type (deprecates os-actions-endpoint-type from DEFAULT group)

commit_message:
Handle region_name in openstack actions

User now could define the region for the openstack actions.
It could be done via API in X-Region-Name and X-Target-Region-Name
in case of multi-vim feature is used.

*API change*
X-Region-Name: Header added to execution create
X-Target-Region-Name: Header added to execution create

Change-Id: Icbf63962a481c1282b95359894fa6245e0e97bac
Related-Bug: #1633345

subject: Fix ZeroDivisionError in reconstructor.stats_line
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-08 02:57:31.000000000', 'files': ['swift/obj/reconstructor.py', 'test/unit/__init__.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_reconstructor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/f4adb2f28f5517772174aac18e3fe9ab1d08c913', 'message': 'Fix ZeroDivisionError in reconstructor.stats_line

Despite a check to prevent zero values in the denominator python
integer division could result in ZeroDivisionError in the compute_eta
helper function.  Make sure we always have a non-zero value even if it
is small.

NotImplemented:

 * stats calculation is still not great, see lp bug #1488608

Closes-Bug: #1549110
Change-Id: I54f2081c92c2a0b8f02c31e82f44f4250043d837
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ZeroDivisionError in reconstructor.stats_line

Despite a check to prevent zero values in the denominator python
integer division could result in ZeroDivisionError in the compute_eta
helper function.  Make sure we always have a non-zero value even if it
is small.

NotImplemented:

 * stats calculation is still not great, see lp bug #1488608

Closes-Bug: #1549110
Change-Id: I54f2081c92c2a0b8f02c31e82f44f4250043d837
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/14/394714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if we ever let a test through without properly patching the # REPLICATE and SSYNC calls - let's fail sort fast-ish self.reconstructor.lockup_timeout = 3 def test_two_ec_policies(self): with patch_policies([ StoragePolicy(0, name='zero', is_deprecated=True), ECStoragePolicy(1, name='one', is_default=True, ec_type=DEFAULT_TEST_EC_TYPE, ec_ndata=4, ec_nparity=3), ECStoragePolicy(2, name='two', ec_type=DEFAULT_TEST_EC_TYPE, ec_ndata=8, ec_nparity=2)], fake_ring_args=[ {}, {'replicas': 7}, {'replicas': 10}]): self._configure_reconstructor() jobs = [] def process_job(job): jobs.append(job) self.reconstructor.process_job = process_job os.makedirs(os.path.join(self.devices, 'sda', 'objects-1', '0')) self.reconstructor.run_once() self.assertEqual(1, len(jobs))

commit_message:
Replace oslo_utils.timeutils.isotime

oslo_utils.timeutils.isotime is deprecated in version '1.6', use
common_utils.isotime instead.

Change-Id: Iad9f41fb7d88a1bee2ca0d0b488ba66856e82bec
Closes-Bug: #1514331

commit_message:
Remove container nodes information from dependents property of cluster

Container nodes information only stores in 'dependents' property
of node, so remove it from cluster property.

Change-Id: I5e2f429b6dffe78bb4ea164517f64720b63e318f

engine support policy delete v2

This patch adds work to support policy-delete2 in engine service layer.

Change-Id: I8bd4e7841f9e1d494d957c1fedba4a86b56e24aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/06/394806/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from senlin.common.i18n import _ def test_policy_delete2(self, mock_find, mock_delete): x_obj = mock.Mock(id='POLICY_ID') mock_find.return_value = x_obj mock_delete.return_value = None req = orpo.PolicyDeleteRequest(identity='POLICY_ID') result = self.eng.policy_delete2(self.ctx, req.obj_to_primitive()) self.assertIsNone(result) self.assertEqual('POLICY_ID', req.identity) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'POLICY_ID') mock_delete.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'POLICY_ID') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find') def test_policy_delete_not_found2(self, mock_find): mock_find.side_effect = exc.ResourceNotFound(type='policy', id='Bogus') req = orpo.PolicyDeleteRequest(identity='Bogus') ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.policy_delete2, self.ctx, req.obj_to_primitive()) self.assertEqual(exc.ResourceNotFound, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual('The policy (Bogus) could not be found.', six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'Bogus') @mock.patch.object(pb.Policy, 'delete') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find') def test_policy_delete_policy_in_use2(self, mock_find, mock_delete): x_obj = mock.Mock(id='POLICY_ID') mock_find.return_value = x_obj err = exc.EResourceBusy(type='policy', id='POLICY_ID') mock_delete.side_effect = err req = orpo.PolicyDeleteRequest(identity='POLICY_ID') ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.policy_delete2, self.ctx, req.obj_to_primitive()) self.assertEqual(exc.ResourceInUse, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual(_("The policy POLICY_ID cannot be deleted: still " "attached to some clusters."), six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'POLICY_ID') mock_delete.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'POLICY_ID') @mock.patch.object(pb.Policy, 'delete') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find')

commit_message:
Make pbr requirement match the setup_requires line

In setup_py_text we setup_requires on pbr>=1.8 - but then in
global-requirements we require >=1.6. It's nothing if not cognitive
dissonance.

Change-Id: Ie948a493c986cc00448c55f00c3d28bd92a73a70

commit_message:
Add a flag to allow the plan to be updated without deploying

This is a stop-gap flag to allow just the plan to be updated. It will
cause the 'deploy' command to do everything up to the point of deploying.

Ideally, there needs to be an 'overcloud plan update' command, but there
currently would be far too much code to duplicate between that command
and the deploy command. They need to be refactored to extract the common
bits into a workflow.

Change-Id: I546babfcbd0d5eafcf777e45187dd493fcfdc1a1
Closes-Bug: #1635301

commit_message:
Send events to all relevant hosts if migrating

Previously, external events were sent to the instance object's host
field. This patch fixes the external event dispatching to check for
migration. If an instance is being migrated, the source and
destination compute are added to the set of hosts to which the event
is sent.

Change-Id: If00736ab36df4a5a3be4f02b0a550e4bcae77b1b
Closes-bug: 1535918
Closes-bug: 1624052
(cherry picked from commit a5b920a197c70d2ae08a1e1335d979857f923b4f)

commit_message:
Remove oslo-incubator modules

Oslo.incubator has become a history. This patch moves the crypto utils
functions to heat.common.crypt.

This also cleans up crypt.py to remove some unused methods.

Co-Authored-By: Rabi Mishra <ramishra@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I439612b37249f0cca041361e647e36643150c3d6

placement handlers are module level functions. Some code is

commit_message:
[placement] Add support for a version_handler decorator

Provide a decorator that allows Placement API handlers to
express a microversion window within which that method should be
used. This makes it possible to define N different methods (with the
same name) to present different behaviors dependent on what
microversion is requested by the user-agent.

If there is no match between a valid requested microversion and
available versioned handlers a 404 response is returned.

The mechanism for managing the versioned handlers is borrowed
from the compute api but adjusted to allow for the fact that
placement handlers are module level functions. Some code is
borrowed from twisted to get fully qualified names of methods for
the VERSION_METHODS dictionary.

Tests are added which validate that versioned handlers do not
intersect. In the rest of nova this is done at runtime, but
in the placement context this isn't necessary. Doing it at testime
is sufficient. Since there are currently no versioned handlers
in addition to the faked tests of the intersection handling I
also manually forced some tests with real handlers, just to be
sure.

Change-Id: I713c139ee12bb7f5301edd85951f8960fda84ac3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/388115/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import inspectMETHODS = collections.defaultdict(list) def __float__(self): return float(self.__str__()) # From twisted # https://github.com/twisted/twisted/blob/trunk/twisted/python/deprecate.py def _fully_qualified_name(obj): """Return the fully qualified name of a module, class, method or function. Classes and functions need to be module level ones to be correctly qualified. """ try: name = obj.__qualname__ except AttributeError: name = obj.__name__ if inspect.isclass(obj) or inspect.isfunction(obj): moduleName = obj.__module__ return "%s.%s" % (moduleName, name) elif inspect.ismethod(obj): try: cls = obj.im_class except AttributeError: # Python 3 eliminates im_class, substitutes __module__ and # __qualname__ to provide similar information. return "%s.%s" % (obj.__module__, obj.__qualname__) else: className = _fully_qualified_name(cls) return "%s.%s" % (className, name) return name def _find_method(f, version_float): """Look in METHODS for method with right name matching version. If no match is found raise a 404 if the request microversion is in the past and a 406 if it is in the present. """ qualified_name = _fully_qualified_name(f) method_list = METHODS[qualified_name] absolute_min_version = float('inf') absolute_max_version = 0 for min_version, max_version, func in method_list: if min_version <= version_float <= max_version: return func if min_version < absolute_min_version: absolute_min_version = min_version if max_version > absolute_max_version: absolute_max_version = max_version if version_float < absolute_min_version: # If the requested version is less than the min_version # required for this method, then as far as this version # is concerned this endpoint doesn't exist, so 404. raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound() else: # We're above the max so our light cone saw a time when # there was a method available so don't 404, 406 instead. raise webob.exc.HTTPNotAcceptable( 'microversion <= %s required' % absolute_max_version) def version_handler(min_ver, max_ver=None): """Decorator for versioning API methods. Add as a decorator to a placement API handler to constrain the microversions at which it will run. Add after the ``wsgify`` decorator. This does not check for version intersections. That's the domain of tests. :param min_ver: A string of two numerals, X.Y indicating the minimum version allowed for the decorated method. :param min_ver: A string of two numerals, X.Y, indicating the maximum version allowed for the decorated method. """ def decorator(f): min_version_float = float(min_ver) if max_ver: max_version_float = float(max_ver) else: max_version_float = max_version_string() qualified_name = _fully_qualified_name(f) METHODS[qualified_name].append( (min_version_float, max_version_float, f)) def decorated_func(req, *args, **kwargs): version_float = float(req.environ[MICROVERSION_ENVIRON]) return _find_method(f, version_float)(req, *args, **kwargs) # Sort highest min version to beginning of list. METHODS[qualified_name].sort(key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True) return decorated_func return decorator

and "--limit" (v2 only) options to "volume backup list" command

commit_message:
Fix 500 error while create/update host

Creating or updating a host with 'type' more than 255 characters
returns 500 error.

This patch fixes the issue by validing the 'type' length upto
255 characters in the schema itself.

Closes-bug: #1640156

Change-Id: I8978a0bae3d6832f2216f56f0303dc3d3996db46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/73/394773/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't assume CountDefault set in roles_data.yaml

Specifying CountDefault in roles_data.yaml is not required since it
defaults to 0 in overcloud.j2.yaml. This patch updates the
_get_default_role_counts to handle the situation where it is not
specified and assume 0 as well.

Change-Id: I4a40b55363d6a4dbe3fdc68309157e04695f51a9
Closes-Bug: #1640141
(cherry picked from commit 4f5be2b7d98347d5fd6ae40ce26fec52749007e9)

commit_message:
m1.tiny is not always there

m1.tiny flavor is hard coded to some tests.
This flavor is not always there, for instance if I don't use devstack.
heat_integrationtests/prepare_test_env.sh creates m1.heat_int flavor
which is the same size as m1.tiny according to the document at
admin-guide/cli-manage-flavors.html

Change-Id: I36524e069eacb36c7e6e7e0297c600ee68be88d6

Change-Id: I7be78248e42c818df45824ce7dc1e51606f7f4d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/65/392965/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Overview -------- The Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) plug-in applies firewalls to OpenStack objects such as projects, routers, router ports, or (anticipated in Ocata) VM ports. The central concepts with OpenStack firewalls are the notions of a firewall policy and a firewall rule. A policy is an ordered collection of rules; a rule specifies a collection of attributes (such as port ranges, protocol, and IP addresses) that constitute match criteria and an action to take (allow or deny) on matched traffic. A policy can be made public, so it can be shared across projects. Firewalls are implemented in various ways depending on the driver used. An iptables driver implements firewalls using iptable rules. An OpenVSwitch driver implements firewall rules using flow entries in flow tables. A Cisco firewall driver manipulates NSX devices. FWaaS v1 -------- The original FWaaS implementation, v1, provides perimeter protection. Here, a firewall is applied at the project-level: all project routers are covered by the policy associated with that firewall so that traffic entering and leaving project networks is vetted. The following diagram depicts FWaaS v1 protection. It illustrates the flow of ingress and egress traffic for the VM2 instance:FWaaS v2 -------- The newer FWaaS implementation, v2, provides a much more granular service. The nomenclature of a "firewall" has been replaced with a "firewall group" to indicate that a firewall consists of two policies: an ingress policy and an egress policy. A firewall group is applied not at the project level (all routers in a project) but at the port level. Currently, router ports can be specified; for Ocata, VM ports can also be specified. In FWaaS v2, each project has a default firewall. This is to say that all ports on all routers in a given project will have a default firewall. FWaaS v1 versus v2 ------------------ The following table compares v1 and v2 features. +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ | Feature | v1 | v2 | +==========================================+=====+======+ | Supports L3 firewalling for routers | YES | NO* | +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ | Supports L3 firewalling for router ports | NO | YES | +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ | Supports L2 firewalling (VM ports) | NO | NO** | +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ | CLI support | YES | YES | +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ | Horizon support | YES | NO | +------------------------------------------+-----+------+ * A firewall group can be applied to all ports on a given router in order to effect this. ** This feature is planned for Ocata.
deleted_lines: Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) overview ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) plug-in adds perimeter firewall management to the OpenStack Networking service. FWaaS uses iptables to apply firewall policy to all neutron routers within a project. FWaaS supports one firewall policy and logical firewall instance per project. Whereas security groups operate at the instance-level, FWaaS operates at the perimeter to filter traffic at the neutron router. The example diagram illustrates the flow of ingress and egress traffic for the VM2 instance:FWaaS version selection ------------------------ Consult this feature matrix to compare features for FWaaS v1 and v2. | Feature | v1 | v2 | | ---------------------------------- | --- | --- | | Supports L3 firewalling (routers) | YES | YES | | Supports L2 firewalling (VM ports) | NO | NO | | CLI support | YES | NO | | Horizon support | YES | NO |

Just monkey-patching yaml.safe_load can break later tests because

Change-Id: I1b8905d1074f7847e51f64d53a9eaa47d063112e
"}]
commit_message:
Mock yaml.safe_load safely

Just monkey-patching yaml.safe_load can break later tests because
it isn't automatically undone after the test completes.  Using
mock.patch to set the mock will handle the cleanup safely.

Change-Id: I1b8905d1074f7847e51f64d53a9eaa47d063112e

commit_message:
Add utility of boolean value parser

We parse the boolean value from string in dict with identical
logic in different areas, it's reasonable to add an util function
to cover this.

Change-Id: Id54029e2e4a0dd2f2093e6ef2583a9cada84c540

added_lines: import mock def _get_fake_binding_response(self): with mock.patch.object(app.neutron, 'list_ports') as mock_list_ports,\ mock.patch.object(app.neutron, 'list_subnets') as mock_list_subnets,\ mock.patch.object(binding, 'port_bind') as mock_port_bind: fake_neutron_network_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self._mock_out_network(fake_neutron_network_id, fake_docker_network_id) fake_neutron_port_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) neutron_port_name = utils.get_neutron_port_name( fake_docker_endpoint_id) fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) fake_neutron_ports_response = self._get_fake_ports( fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_network_id, fake_neutron_port_id, fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id, fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id) mock_list_ports.return_value = fake_neutron_ports_response fake_neutron_subnets_response = self._get_fake_subnets( fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_network_id, fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id, fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id) mock_list_subnets.return_value = fake_neutron_subnets_response fake_neutron_port = fake_neutron_ports_response['ports'][0] fake_neutron_subnets = fake_neutron_subnets_response['subnets'] fake_message = "fake message" fake_exception = GivenException(fake_message) mock_port_bind.side_effect = fake_exception response = self._invoke_join_request(fake_docker_network_id, fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_container_id) self.assertEqual(w_exceptions.InternalServerError.code, response.status_code) decoded_json = jsonutils.loads(response.data) self.assertIn('Err', decoded_json) self.assertIn(fake_message, decoded_json['Err']) mock_list_ports.assert_called_once_with(name=neutron_port_name) mock_list_subnets.assert_called_once_with( network_id=fake_neutron_network_id) mock_port_bind.assert_called_once_with(fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_port, fake_neutron_subnets)
deleted_lines: def _port_bind_with_exeption(self, docker_endpiont_id, neutron_port, neutron_subnets, ex): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(binding, 'port_bind') if ex: binding.port_bind( docker_endpiont_id, neutron_port, neutron_subnets).AndRaise(ex) else: binding.port_bind( docker_endpiont_id, neutron_port, neutron_subnets).AndReturn( fake_binding_response) self.mox.ReplayAll() fake_neutron_network_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self._mock_out_network(fake_neutron_network_id, fake_docker_network_id) fake_neutron_port_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.mox.StubOutWithMock(app.neutron, 'list_ports') neutron_port_name = utils.get_neutron_port_name( fake_docker_endpoint_id) fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) fake_neutron_ports_response = self._get_fake_ports( fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_network_id, fake_neutron_port_id, fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id, fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id) app.neutron.list_ports(name=neutron_port_name).AndReturn( fake_neutron_ports_response) self.mox.StubOutWithMock(app.neutron, 'list_subnets') fake_neutron_subnets_response = self._get_fake_subnets( fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_network_id, fake_neutron_v4_subnet_id, fake_neutron_v6_subnet_id) app.neutron.list_subnets(network_id=fake_neutron_network_id).AndReturn( fake_neutron_subnets_response) fake_neutron_port = fake_neutron_ports_response['ports'][0] fake_neutron_subnets = fake_neutron_subnets_response['subnets'] fake_message = "fake message" fake_exception = GivenException(fake_message) self._port_bind_with_exeption( fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_neutron_port, fake_neutron_subnets, fake_exception) self.mox.ReplayAll() response = self._invoke_join_request( fake_docker_network_id, fake_docker_endpoint_id, fake_container_id) self.assertEqual( w_exceptions.InternalServerError.code, response.status_code) decoded_json = jsonutils.loads(response.data) self.assertIn('Err', decoded_json) self.assertIn(fake_message, decoded_json['Err'])

commit_message:
Update --endpoint-type dest to os_endpoint_type

Currently the dest of the deprecated --endpoint-type arg
is 'endpoint_type'. However, the code only uses 'os_endpoint_type'
so right now it isn't being used at all. This patch updates
the dest to be 'os_endpoint_type' so that the variable can
be assigned correctly.

Change-Id: Ie8592d12bcf95e4ccff571e831440b18f5acfd40
Closes-bug: #1454436
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/80/351880/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix random DB unit test failure

Depending on the generated IDs for the flow classifiers, the following
test can fail:
networking_sfc.tests.unit.services.sfc.test_plugin.SfcPluginTestCase.test_update_port_chain_add_flow_classifiers

Sample traceback:
  File "networking_sfc/tests/unit/db/test_sfc_db.py", line 823, in test_update_port_chain_add_flow_classifiers
    self.assertEqual(res['port_chain'][k], v)
  File "/root/networking-sfc/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 411, in assertEqual
    self.assertThat(observed, matcher, message)
  File "/root/networking-sfc/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 498, in assertThat
    raise mismatch_error
testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: !=:
reference = [u'59149477-9171-4b68-9d65-e8a455c87699',
 u'b068f7f6-78ed-47b0-97f8-d0acfd026aff']
actual    = [u'b068f7f6-78ed-47b0-97f8-d0acfd026aff',
 u'59149477-9171-4b68-9d65-e8a455c87699']

This fixes the test by asserting items equality for lists (like the
flow classifiers). Other tests using the same asssertion were also updated

commit_message:
"Unable to retrieve Domain" incessant warning logs

"openstack_dashboard.api.keystone: Unable to retrieve Domain: default"
incessant warning logging when switching Projects while being on the
Identity>Project panel.

Retrieving domain information is a Keystone admin URL operation. As a
pre-check, such operations would be Forbidden if the logon user does not
have an 'admin' role on the current project.

Since this is a common occurence, and can cause incessant warning
logging in the horizon logs, we recognize this condition and return the
user's domain information instead.

Signed-off-by: Kam Nasim <kam.nasim@windriver.com>

Closes-Bug: #1638662
Change-Id: Iadd5184a16a73da1da5a7230c89e996248f1eba7
(cherry picked from commit 55baf9254d78de2c6e409156e6649875cb7797e3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/70/394870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except exceptions.NotAuthorized: # NOTE (knasim-wrs): Retrieving domain information # is an admin URL operation. As a pre-check, such # operations would be Forbidden if the logon user does # not have an 'admin' role on the current project. # # Since this can be a common occurence and can cause # incessant warning logging in the horizon logs, # we recognize this condition and return the user's # domain information instead. LOG.debug("Cannot retrieve domain information for " "user (%s) that does not have an admin role " "on project (%s)" % (request.user.username, request.user.project_name))

commit_message:
Allow snapshot deletion after volume transfer

Currently snapshot deletion fails if the parent volume is
transferred to a different user. This patch uses admin
context to query the volume so that parent volume can be
retrieved and deletion can proceed without VolumeNotFound
exception.

Closes-bug: #1632997
Change-Id: I5f290e7e4732a17742a1ff277f574fc73c0f64de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/39/385839/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note(vbala) Parent volume may belong to a different user; use # admin context to query the volume. volume = objects.Volume.get_by_id(context.elevated(), snapshot.volume_id)

commit_message:
Update upper limit for pylxd to 2.1.1

pylxd 2.1.2 removes a backwards-compatible reference
to deprecated code. Upstream thought it was a good idea,
until the tests for stable/newton of nova-lxd began breaking.

Unfortunately, in order to fix the incompatibility, we had to pin
2.1.1 in stable/newton. When looking at stable/newton of requirements,
however, it's WAY out of date for what master had when newton was released.
This patch looks like we're adding versions to upper constraints, when
we're really updating requirements to reflect what nova-lxd already
supports.

Fixes bug 1638037

Change-Id: I1ddb752d4045d040f597683696013e8a4eadf741

    tools/ironic/scripts/setup-network.sh

Change-Id: If06f079bed16d9c84569594aa64259bf06f91a1e
"}]
commit_message:
Add PS4 for better logfile information of devstack runs

The scripts
    tools/ironic/scripts/cleanup-node.sh
    tools/ironic/scripts/create-node.sh
    tools/ironic/scripts/setup-network.sh

are executed by sudo and the PS4 value disappears during sudo. Add a
PS4 value so that we get better logs during their execution.

PS4 is used to prefix the tracing output when using:
    'set -x' or 'set -o xtrace'

From the bash manpage:
PS4     The  value  of this parameter is expanded as with PS1 and the
        value is printed before each command bash displays during an
        execution trace.  The first character of PS4 is replicated
        multiple times, as necessary, to indicate multiple levels of
        indirection.  The default is ``+ ''.

Change-Id: If06f079bed16d9c84569594aa64259bf06f91a1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/08/394608/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Make tracing more educational export PS4='+ ${BASH_SOURCE:-}:${FUNCNAME[0]:-}:L${LINENO:-}: '

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Neutron-vpnaas Scorecard ======================== Neutron integration ------------------- .. _N0: * N0. As a non-starter, does the project use the Neutron REST API or relies on proprietary backends? .. _N1: * N1. Does the project integrate/use neutron-lib? .. _N2: * N2. Does project members actively contribute to help neutron-lib achieve its goal? .. _N3: * N3. Does project members collaborate with the core team to enable subprojects to loosely integrate with the Neutron core platform by helping with the definition of modular interfaces? .. _N4: * N4. How does the project provide networking services? Does it use modular interfaces as provided by the core platform? .. _N5: * N5. If the project provides new API extensions, have API extensions been discussed and accepted by the Neutron drivers team? Please provide links to API specs, if required. Documentation ------------- .. _D1: * D1. Does the project have a doc tox target, functional and continuously working? Provide proof (links to logs.openstack.org). .. _D2: * D2. If the project provide API extensions, does the project have an api-ref tox target, functional and continously working? Provide proof (links to logs.openstack.org). .. _D3: * D3. Does the project have a releasenotes tox target, functional and continously working? Provide proof. .. _D4: * D4. Describe the types of documentation available: developer, end user, administrator, deployer. Continuous Integration ---------------------- .. _C1: * C1. Does the project have a Grafana dashboard showing historical trends of all the jobs available? Provide proof (links to grafana.openstack.org). .. _C2: * C2. Does the project have CI for unit coverage? Provide proof (links to logs.openstack.org) .. _C3: * C3. Does the project have CI for functional coverage? If so, does it include DB migration and sync validation? .. _C4: * C4. Does the project have CI for fullstack coverage? .. _C5: * C5. Does the project have CI for Tempest coverage? If so, specify nature (API and/or Scenario). .. _C6: * C6. Does the project require CI for Grenade coverage? .. _C7: * C7. Does the project provide multinode CI? .. _C8: * C8. Does the project support Python 3.x? Provide proof. Release footprint ----------------- .. _R1: * R1. Does the project adopt semver? .. _R2: * R2. Does the project have release deliverables? Provide proof as available in the `release repo <http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/releases/tree/>`_. Stable backports ---------------- .. _S1: * S1. Does the project have stable branches and/or tags? Provide history of backports. Client library -------------- .. _L1: * L1. If the project requires a client library, how does it implement CLI and API bindings? Scorecard --------- +---------------+ | Scorecard | +===============+ | N0_ | +|- | +---------------+ | N1_ | +|- | +---------------+ | N2_ | +|- | +---------------+ | N3_ | +|- | +---------------+ | N4_ | +|- | +---------------+ | N5_ | +|- | +---------------+ | D1_ | +|- | +---------------+ | D2_ | +|- | +---------------+ | D3_ | +|- | +---------------+ | D4_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C1_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C2_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C3_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C4_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C5_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C6_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C7_ | +|- | +---------------+ | C8_ | +|- | +---------------+ | R1_ | +|- | +---------------+ | R2_ | +|- | +---------------+ | S1_ | +|- | +-----+---------+ | L1_ | +|- | +-----+---------+ Final remarks: (To be compiled by PTL).

commit_message:
Update hacking requirements

Set it to >=0.12.0

The Ironic and Neutron projects both want to use the feature:
  [H904] Delay string interpolations at logging calls.

This feature was introduced in 0.12.0 release.

Change-Id: I2aa44b62f900d4dfd67701b01eadd0523fbfaf07

commit_message:
Disable q-dhcp in the devstackgaterc job

devstackgaterc job is failing in gate. When q-dhcp is disabled,
it is passing.
This patch disables the q-dhcp and makes use of the native dhcp as a
temporary solution to fix this issue.
q-dhcp needs to be enabled back once the issue is fixed properly.

Please see the bug description for more details.

Change-Id: I03aaceead620b8e312823a872ef95c42df673252
Partial-bug: #1639806

commit_message:
Reword description of grace

Now Zaqar uses "claim expiration time > current message TTL"
to judge whether to extend message ttl or not.
The explanation of grace "If a claimed message would normally
live longer than the grace period, its expiration is not adjusted."
is not very clear to users.

So we reword the description of grace to "If a claimed message
would normally live longer than the claim's live period,
its expiration is not adjusted."

Change-Id: Ib9b042e99116fb4c4656696d413a778e4f07f4c6
Closes-Bug: #1632629

Add experimental pep8 to python-(db-)jobs

To avoid some chrun to project config, add the experimental pep8 job
to python-jobs / python-db-jobs templates.

We'll be reverting this commit in a weeks time.

commit_message:
Prevent nova from booting VMs directly on trunk subports

Before nova goes on and schedules a VM, it checks for the
port's device_id and if it is set, it throws an InUse error
to the user and stops proceeding. We want the same behavior
for trunk subports, which are not meant to be used directly.

Closes-bug: #1636485

Change-Id: I2c1fc8efde70ff078e694e959abb29535bfa854c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/393960/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron._i18n import _, _LEfrom neutron import manager registry.subscribe(self._update_port_device_id, constants.SUBPORTS, events.AFTER_CREATE) registry.subscribe(self._update_port_device_id, constants.SUBPORTS, events.AFTER_DELETE) def _update_port_device_id(self, resource, event, triggers, **kwargs): payload = kwargs['payload'] core_plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin() if event == events.AFTER_CREATE: _id = payload.trunk_id _owner = constants.TRUNK_SUBPORT_OWNER elif event == events.AFTER_DELETE: _id = '' _owner = '' port_data = {'port': {'device_id': _id, 'device_owner': _owner}} for subport in payload.subports: try: core_plugin.update_port( payload.context, subport.port_id, port_data) except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Unable to update device_id='%(device_id)s' " "and device_owner='%(device_owner)s' " "for port=%(port_id)s: %(reason)s."), {'device_id': _id, 'device_owner': _owner, 'port_id': subport.port_id, 'reason': e})

commit_message:
Don't send confirmation notification if it's not enabled

Currently even though the 'require_confirmation' option is False,
Zaqar will send the confirmation notification anyway, which is
breaking the backward compatibility. This patch will fix it and
add a test for that.

Closes-Bug: #1633222

Change-Id: I2d6363feab90ff737684d5c1d903c2c2d7abe106

commit_message:
Ensure apparmor is running before reloading

The 'Reload apparmor' handler can fail if the apparmor service is not
already in a running state. Add an additional handler to ensure that
apparmor is started and enabled on boot.

Change-Id: If2752d69beb2c646a64f2ca02ce39a0d4161a5b5
(cherry picked from commit 3f0c8f642fa7bf4e4075801071b68f3a6e306b85)

deleted_lines: from debtcollector import removals@removals.remove( message="use get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64 from oslo_utils.netutils", version="Newton", removal_version="Ocata") def get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64(prefix, mac): # Check if the prefix is IPv4 address isIPv4 = netaddr.valid_ipv4(prefix) if isIPv4: msg = _("Unable to generate IP address by EUI64 for IPv4 prefix") raise TypeError(msg) try: eui64 = int(netaddr.EUI(mac).eui64()) prefix = netaddr.IPNetwork(prefix) return netaddr.IPAddress(prefix.first + eui64 ^ (1 << 57)) except (ValueError, netaddr.AddrFormatError): raise TypeError(_('Bad prefix or mac format for generating IPv6 ' 'address by EUI-64: %(prefix)s, %(mac)s:') % {'prefix': prefix, 'mac': mac}) except TypeError: raise TypeError(_('Bad prefix type for generate IPv6 address by ' 'EUI-64: %s') % prefix)
